review.des:
This is a nice-looking restaurant, but sadly, for a meal that ended up costing me around $60, the food was pretty underwhelming. I ordered some tea, 2 appetizers (steamed basket and fried platter), and a bowl of beef brisket noodles. All items were sub-par.

The beef brisket noodles lacked flavor - from both the brisket and the broth. Texture-wise, the beef was very dry and the noodles seemed to fall apart very easily, as if they were not freshly cooked. Considering it was $16, the toppings were also very sparse - pretty much just a few greens and some cilantro. I'm willing to pay more in this type of setting, but perhaps not twice the price for half the usual quality.

The appetizers were a bit finicky - they looked really cute, but everything lacked substance. Portions were pretty small for $12 each. The spring rolls were sparsely filled with veggies and almost everything lacked flavor (even the dipping sauces!).

If you really want to try this place, it's the type of place where you want to go on a date that you're not paying for and you also don't really want to commit to that person cuz they probably don't have taste buds.

Imperial Lamian was on my list for places to visit in Chicago, and I couldn't be more excited.

I love the interior design and the decoration of the place. I thought it was genius. I love the view of the bird cages light fixture when you first walk in. Furthermore, the restaurant used the design of a abacus as a divider between booths.
Our waiter was friendly and very caring. He took care of our table very well and I did not have any complaint.
The food were delicious! As someone who LOVE dim sum, this place definitely did not disappoint. I ordered the combination soup dumplings along with the duck and truffle soup dumplings. They were full of flavors. From the first bite to the last, I was able to fully get all the decadent flavor of the soup and the meat were perfectly seasoned. I also ordered shrimp siu mai and har gow. I am really happy with how they turned out. Everything were just so delicious.
Overall, I really enjoyed my time at Imperial Lamian. I would definitely come back here with my friends next time.

We came here for lunch because warm noodle soup was called for thanks to the 45 degree rainy weather. We order the char siu and wonton noodle soup, truffle and szechuan soup dumplings.

We were told that all of the dishes are made for family style meals, so the portion sizes were large enough to share. While there were plenty of noodles in the dish, I wish there was more broth to make it seem more of a soup dish. The dumplings were also not quite as 'soupy' as I was expecting, but they were tasty and held together well. Service was great which is always a plus!

Came here during happy hour after work with some friends. The decor is really upscale and it is certainly more "fancy" Chinese food as compared to any other place I've been to in Chicago that I can think of right now. The happy hour is essentially half off of select foods which makes it pretty good value.

I got the Szechuan wontons, beef brisket hand shaven noodles, pork belly gua bao and the typhoon as well as a saketini (which wasn't on the menu!). The Szechuan wontons I definitely wish had thinner wonton skin and was a bit spicier, but was good as a dish if they weren't one of my favorite dishes in Asia. The pork belly gua bao was surprisingly good, the guabao was thin and kind of came apart when you tried to pull it out of the steamer, but the pork belly was flavored really well, thick and delicious and just fatty enough.

Both of the cocktails were good as well, the saketini being surprisingly strong, it tasted mostly like cucumber and I enjoyed it despite not liking sake too much. The beef brisket noodles were a very small portion to my surprise, but the happy hour menu calls it "a bite of noodles" in Mandarin anyway so it is true to form. The noodles were well made and tasty and to my surprise it was clear bone marrow soup instead of braised soup which is the more common form of beef noodle in the States. The beef I felt could be braised longer so the taste really permeates, but overall not bad.

I've heard the seasonal fish is pretty good, and I would love to try that if I were to visit again!

I'm not fond of the colored dough, but the traditional xiao long bao (soup dumplings) at Imperial Lamian are the real deal. I've had both the traditional pork and the crab version here, and they've been perfectly balanced and very flavorful. I highly recommend both.

With the exception of the string beans with minced pork and olives (a fine version, but tiny portion), and the Hainan Rice (which is very hard to find and excellent here), you can really pass on everything else at Imperial Lamian. The lamian (hand-pulled) noodles are fresh, but the broths and wok-fries in which they are served are disappointingly pedestrian. Same for everything else I've tried from the dinner menu.  

Stick to the XLB. I will defintely come back for the xiaolongbao, but probably wouldn't order anything else here again.

The chef recommended squid ink Lamian was less than stellar. The noodles were somewhat irregular and stiff, not chewy or bouncy in a good way. A good amount of shrimp and bok choy though and the broth had a solid shrimpiness that wasn't fishy or overkill. See the pictures

The xlb weren't great either. The skin was an okay thickness, we can't all be din tai dung. However the broth within was missing a sweet porcine note. It had flavor but I could have believed it was a chicken broth inside.
Ambiance=Cute.. Service=Great.. Food=MEDIOCRE AT BEST especially for the price. This is why you am never really trust yelp reviews for Asian places.. I knew better but wanted to try it out.

Simply good eating! Great place for a date night culinary adventure, everything from dinner to dessert was phenomenal and flavorful. I highly recommend the lunar dessert for something new and exciting for your tastebuds.

We came here because my gf was really craving Asian Food on a cold Chicago day.

It's very interesting when you enter the restaurant and you can see everyone working to make your food. The women that work in the back look like they are constantly busy and moving. But you can see everything come out fresh and it's very eye catching. The amount of effort these ladies put into making the food makes you really excited to put it in your mouth.

I will say that I was very satisfied with the food and the service. We ordered the assorted dumplings, the chicken lamian noodles, and the chocolate lunar blossom. The dumplings tasted great, the noodles were fresh, and the dessert was out of this world. I think we surprised our waiter when the 2 of us finished the entire dessert.

It's great we came at happy hour because you can get a lot for a little. If I come back to Chicago, I'll be sure to pay this place a visit once more.

Soup Dumplings!!!!! They have been a favorite for a number of years so I truly enjoyed them! All of the soup dumplings have some pork, so be aware.

The food was great!

Staff was friendly and helpful.

The space is beautiful.

Pro tip: Make sure to ask for individual sauces for each person in your party.

Went here for HH yesterday. The food knocked it out of the park. We ordered a variety of things - I should have taken more photos but I was way to into eating to remember to snap a pic!  I would highly recommend them for their cuisine and the prices can't be beat.

I am knocking them down a star based on their drink choices for HH. The house red was just so so. However at $5 a glass I probably shouldn't complain. They also offered a pitcher of Sapporo for $15. I guess my main complaint is that there just wasn't enough beverage choices at HH prices. Isn't 80% of the point of HH the drinks?? Maybe that's just me?

I was a little skeptical because this place seemed a bit Americanized but the food was actually tasty. It's a little pricey and the portions aren't that big but I would come back again because I thought the food was delicious.

Not the drinks. The drinks were pretty bad. My friend got a pumpkin boba tea and it tasted super sour. The boba was also rock hard. She got another drink, some orange mystery, but she thought that didn't taste so great either. There was a weird after taste.

The food:

-Truffle xiao long bao: good! The truffle oil smell really hits you in the face. The soup was not that hot though.
-Duck xiao long bao: I don't know why the outer skin was green. It was green and it looked kind of gross. However, I thought the duck meat inside was quite rich though.
-Gan bian si ji dou (green beans): I liked it! The portion size was so small though. The green beans were cooked enough that they were on the drier side which is how it should be. It was the tiniest bit of spicy.
-Pork belly noodle soup: decent. I'm not a huge fan of noodle soups so while I did think the noodles were fresh, this isn't a dish I'd be clamoring to get next time. I am curious about the la mian (dry) so I'll try that next time.

It was about $18/person (not including the drink).

Decent place. I've walked past this place hundreds of times but finally decided to stop by and to get out of the rain.

Service wasn't the best. Waitress forgot my order after taking it and forgot sauce for my appetizer. I asked for a drink with a slight modification and she told me it couldn't be done. Huh? Then she considered the possibility of modifying if I had an allergy. Huh? I think using a simple syrup instead of a flavored syrup shouldn't be a big deal. I guess she reconciled it in her mind after much introspection, then brought it out by the time I had finished my appetizer and was midway through my meal. She apologized for that and that's cool, but I'm still uncertain why she was being weird in the first place.

Mixed Mushroom Lamian was OK. Is it miso broth? Is it veggie tomato broth? Is it both? The flavors are kind of a mindf^ck.

Veggie Basket was delicious. I'd come back for that.

If you're looking for something different than your usual eats, this place provides that.

pics.caption: Veggie Basket 2 spring rolls, 2 buns, 2 XLBs. 2 Yummy!

review.des:
Table for 4, walk-in on a Tues eve around 7PM, and promptly seated.

Nice decor, dimly lit, good ambiance

Wonton soup was super salty - had to add 5 cups of hot water. Wontons were decent.

Placed an delivery order through Yelp which had an ETA of 40 mins. After over 90mins of waiting I called the restaurant and was informed it had been picked up 40 mins ago and for me to call grubhub in regards to the delivery status. After calling grubhub their customer service rep informed me that it is another 15mins. I was only 2 blocks away from the restaurant which is less than 5 min drive. I had cancelled the order

Although I had not eaten anything from the restaurant and can't critic about the food, I gave it a 1 star because the restaurant should also take responsibility as they chose to use an  unreliable 3rd party company such as yelp and grubhub to sell their product.

Seriously? All my XLB stuck to the bottom of the liner which was not paper (which it should be) but a plastic liner. The skins were also very thick. Come on, this is something so basic.

The mushroom baos were cute but the use of cinnamon was odd and off putting.

Nothing was exceptional, including the service for the price.

UPDATE: After our negative first impressions with Imperial Lamian, we were invited back for a second meal. This time around, we were truly blown away by the service and the quality of food.

My favorite dishes were definitely the Fried Dimsum Platter, the Char Siu Wonton Lamian, and the Lunar Blossom.

The Fried Dimsum Platter contained 2x Pumpkin Puffs, 2x Crispy Wontons, and 2x Spring Rolls. It was hard picking out one as my favorite because all three were so unique, so I would just recommend getting two of each kind. You won't be disappointed with any of them.

The Char Siu and Wonton Lamian was a marked improvement over the bowl of lamian I had two weeks ago. Just as before, the hand-pulled noodles were very firm and chewy. This time around however, the bok choy was actually really good and the soup was umami.

The Lunar Blossom was the most extravagant desert I've ever had and something that I've previously only seen on Facebook videos. Basically, its piece of cake topped with gelatto inside of a white chocolate shell that blossoms open when your server pours hot dark chocolate on it. The presentation and taste blew me away.

We will definitely be back for more.

pics.caption: Lunar Blossom: beautiful presentation and taste; definitely try it especially if you have a sweet tooth
Jasmine Tea Smoked Ribs*: although they were very good, they kind of just tasted like normal ribs to me (I'm not sure where the jasmine was)
Shanghai Xiao Long Bao (white) & Spicy Szechuan Xiao Long Bao (red): my favorites from the Combination Xiao Long Bao

review.des:
I enjoyed. I'd say the atmosphere and decor was upscale/trendy which I found unusual but welcome for a Chinese place. Lots of marble everywhere- which I love.

The Szechuan Wontons are an amazing starter if you enjoy spicy foods. That dish alone was 5 stars. Very succulent with just the right amount of spice.

I ordered the Duck Fried Rice for my main meal and it was just okay. I've had many better fried rice dishes so I don't think I'd ever order this again.

Overall, I had a great experience and would go back to perhaps try the La Mian noodles next time!

Food is great, SERVICE IS HORRIBLE.
Waiter is very pushing, cold face all the time. Asked us to order when we just seated and brought the check when we hadn't finished our food. We asked them to clean the soup from dumplings on the table, but they never came. The two stars are all for their service. I would give five stars to the food.

Definitely check this place out!! I heard about it from fellow Eliter Denise when she was raving about this place. I had it bookmarked for a month before I went. My friend and I went for happy hour and sat at the bar. Happy hour is until 6pm on weekdays and includes four dumpling options and $12 create your own la miam bowls and some adult beverage options.

We got the pumpkin dumplings and they came out like little pumpkins!! Didn't even look edible they looked so much like descriptions! They were delicious too. We got the shrimp and one other dumplings as well. Those came in 4 while the pumpkin had 3.

We went with the beef brisket la miam and hand pulled noodles. Yummmm!!! We split all of that and we were good in terms of feeling full from the portions.

My original intention was to come in to try the lunar blossom dessert which I saw a video of on Instagram but was feeling too full so I've made it my mission to try it so I will absolutely be back!!

I came here for happy hour a couple of weeks ago. I ordered the shrimp dumplings (fresh and tasty) and bbq pork noodle soup (why is the bowl concave? It makes it harder to eat from the bowl. Why are the noodles separate? The noodles are cold and clumped together by the time it arrives in front of you. Try dumping a bowl of clumped together noodles into a bowl that can barely fit everything. My dumpling was raw and I had to ask for a new one).

It was pretty quiet and the happy hour deal is good but only until 6PM.

During my trip to Chicago, their Combination Xiao Long Bao was probably my favorite food that I ate. I remembered from a Facebook video that there was a rainbow soup dumpling place in Chicago so I had to use Google to find this place.

Their XLB were so juicy but I think the experience of eating them was probably my favorite. Say you order something from a restaurant--it's most likely a large portion of the same things. For this, each bite is something different and you get to experience these unique flavors. Although a bit pricey ($12 for 6), I think it was well worth it for the experience. Keep in mind that it will not fill most people up.

The flavors--gruyere cheese, duck, traditional Shanghai pork, truffle, spicy Szechuan​, and crab--were pretty spot on of what it was supposed to be. The gruyere cheese was surprisingly​ good and not a bad combination at all.

The pumpkin puff, which is butternut squash and duck, wasn't all that great and I could have done without it.

I think because I like to excite my taste buds but also because they were actually very tasty, it was a 5-star experience in my book!

WOW!  Brittney has great recommendations and explained the menu well. Easy to make reservations and the food was amazing. Can't wait to go back and try more! We ordered three things to share and it was perfect!

This place has an amazing vibe. I really loved the interior of the restaurant. Low lighting, downtown atmosphere--pretty chic. However, don't let this atmosphere fool you.

This place desires to be a high end Chinese restaurant, but it's missing the mark with the quality of food being served to its patrons.

The prices are pretty steep for the dishes, so we thought dishes would be perfect for family style (there were four of us). WRONG. What a tease! The dishes might be best for two hungry folks and maybe a third person who eats small portions.

I didn't find the food to be that great, either. The rice was dry, the beef was over cooked, and the noodles were meh.

Service was great. Our waiter was attentive, and the manager was walking the restaurant.

If and when I return to Chicago, I'll be on the hunt for a better Chinese food experience. I like to eat, so I'm going to need way more food for these prices!

I thought the food was hit or miss and over priced.
Good: shanghai Xiao long Bao, properly soupy on the inside with proper sauce.
Bad: beef noodles and pork noodles. For having lamien on the restaurant name, the noodles were a joke.  The texture was not chewy at all. The taste was bland. The meat was at least tender and flavorful.
Shenjian bao was mushy on the inside which made it gross to eat. Definitely not worth it.
Overall would not come back.

Imperial lamian was fairly decent, I'm a harsh critic when it comes to Chinese food and I decided to come here with two girlfriends seeking "Instagram worthy" food after seeing their soup dumplings all over the web.

We ordered:
Salted egg yolk green beans: good portion for $9,
Fairly standard.

Soup dumplings:
These were disappointing. Very little soup for XLB, the crab one didn't taste like crab; the Szechuan peppercorn one had some spice but otherwise was just pork. Would not get these again especially since 6 are $12.

Half glutinous pumpkin bun and half fried wonton with shrimp: this was delicious, I enjoyed the pumpkin shaped bun stuffed with mushrooms and pork as well as the big shrimp wontons.

Pork belly la Mian: this was good, but nothing to write home about. $14 for a bowl of soup, one of their cheaper dining options.

Their pandan cake globe dessert is hefty priced at $15. However it is a showstopper for sure. Waitress pours chocolate and the shell dissolved before your eyes revealing pandan cake with almonds. You won't be able to eat the white chocolate shell, it is too sweet. Just eat the vanilla ice cream with chocolate syrup and pandan. I would get this again to impress guests, otherwise skip out on it since very few parts of the dessert are actually edible unless your sweet tooth is big.

We spent $25 per person, which wasn't too bad, the decor is classic and nice, good date spot, and service is decent as expected for a high class downtown establishment.

I recently attended a Yelp Event with Denyce M and she told me and another friend about Imperial in which I have worked not too far from for about 5 years and never thought about going in. She mentioned a happy hour menu that caught our ears.

Me and my lovely friend came by recently and got seats at the bar. Looked around and checked out the really nice atmosphere with exposed brick and dim lighting which is always my favorite look in a restaurant. There was even an awesome mural of a woman in the bar area. We were there for the $5 each dim sum happy hour menu so we shared 3 sets of dumplings; pork soup dumplings (my favorite), butternut squash/roast duck pumpkin puffs and shrimp dumplings. They were all very good. We then shared a Lamian in which it was build your own. We had hand shaved noodles, beef brisket and beef broth...very good!

My friend actually saw an IG post of one of their extravagant hot chocolate cakes but we were too full to order, but def next time around. Pretty good drink menu as I had the East Meets West which is an asian old fashioned as described to me by the guy behind the bar. It included Japanese whiskey which is my favorite. They also carry my favorite Japanese whiskey here, Yamazaki 12 year. Good spot and as I said I would like to come back for that cake as well as their normal dinner menu.

My family and I were in the mood for some asian deliciousness and this was close to our hotel. The staff was super friendly. Everyone we interacted with was polite, smiling, and helpful. The atmosphere was casual and a bit hip. We tried the dim sum sampler, salted egg fried beans, and the beef brisket lamian. With a hot tea, bill was $50.
Food came super quick. The reason for only 4 stars was that the food didn't meet my expectations. It was good but not super good.
Jasmine took amazing care of us and patiently answered our questions.
We would definitely try it again.
The food is awesome and the server, Danilo does a great and get us very good services. Will return more often.

Wanted to try some soup dumplings, reserved on open table for a Sunday night. Tad bit wait for our table but the Manager was very compassionate and sent over 3 appetizers which were on point. The food choices and our selections did not disappoint. I have had better soup dumplings but the restaurant had a great homey feel. The waitress Britt was amazing and on target with her recommendations. We kept seeing a large ball being served for dessert and it peaked our curiosity and it did not disappoint. Great price for the amount of food we got. Highly recommended.

I came here with a few friends after winning an Instagram contest for a cocktail making class. We met with the beverage manager, Gerardo, who set everything up for us. After getting to know all of the tools and ingredients needed, we got our drinks on. I was excited that the lineup included 2 traditional then 2 variations of those traditional drinks: an Old Fashioned, East Meets West, a Manhattan, and a Tokyo Manhattan. I appreciated that Gerardo not only walked us through everything but was teaching us so much history about the drinks, Imperial Lamian, as well as getting personal with us too.

The reason I appreciated the drink selection was that I'm not much of a whiskey drinker, simply because I didn't know HOW to drink it (I can't order drinks neat. I'm sorry, I wish I could). I'm happy to say I'd confidently order a Manhattan all by myself now!

Obviously if I had drank all 4 of my drinks in the early afternoon, I would have been carried out. My friends and I feasted on some dim sum pairings with our drinks (Thanks Gerardo!) - I'd have to say the XLB (aka xiao long bao aka soup dumplings) have been calling my name for over a year now and I'm so happy I finally got to try them! I also truly loved the Imperial Lamian version of "shrimp toast". And the highlight of our experience was the cute little piggy bao! So cute, but not TOO cute to NOT eat.

I'm definitely coming back, specifically for the dim sum menu. But then again, everything at Imperial looks great.. I'll need to ensure the flavor matches the eye candy ;)

I have been on a quest to find the best soup dumplings in Chicago, and so far Imperial Lamian is hands down the best!

Not to forget that the service was actually amazing. Jasmine knew the menu inside out, and was so incredibly friendly. Jasmine gets 11/10 stars.

Will definitely be back!

Imperial Lamian was recommended to me after a friend found out I was on a food trip in Chicago.  And although it's on the pricey side, it really did fix my Asian cravings! The service was prompt and friendly and the decor in the restaurant is awesome. We went for happy hour on a Friday night.

I got the combination xiao long bao (rainbow colored soup dumplings), calamari (not pictured) and pumpkin puffs.  

The calamari was delicious! I'd highly recommend it as an appetizer.  The pumpkin puffs were just okay in my opinion but my fiancé really enjoyed them. They just reminded me of a meat pie to be honest.

Now the combination xiao long bao comes with six different types. And if you're like me you will want to save the best flavors for last when sampling them!  

I ate mine in this exact order:

1. Shanghai pork
2. Gruyere
3. Spicy Szechuan
4. Crab
5. Duck
6. Truffle (Save the truffle for last or order more! It's delicious)

I'd also recommend the lunar blossom for dessert. The presentation is pretty cool so get your phones out and start recording.

The Chinese food here cannot be defined as authentic, but the food is absolutely palatable.
We tried pork belly noodles, London Duck and 6 different Xiaolongbao.
The pork belly in the noodle is well stewed and the skin on the pork belly is gently fried which provides a rich flavor.
Although the it is called London Duck, the duck is cooked based on Peking duck style. They use pulled duck meat instead of sliced duck. They provide sliced onions and cucumbers on the side. The dish is successfully Americanized.
Xiaolongbao is not that outstanding but they let you try six flavors in one dish which is nice.

Wait : they accept rsvp
Service : not very friendly with Chicago standard, as I used to live in New York, that's okay. One annoying thing is the girl keep asking to take the dish away while we haven't finished eating.
xiao Lao bao is worth the try, I wish the wrap dough be thinner n more broth inside.
I tried Szechuan la Mian : broth is tasty but noodle is on the harder side.
Vibe : great decoration with lots of rooms between each table.
Price : a little overpriced for the food
Tip : I won't try the noodle again, might go there to try some other things.

Trendy-upscale Chinese cuisine. Accessible location.

Good:
- Calamari - amazingly good. I would get again.
- Crab soup dumplings were the best of the lot. I still prefer the more authentic variety in Chinatown. we ordered a couple of different ones (shanghai, kimchi, duck, crab). I wasn't too impressed with the other soup dumplings as they were either uncooked or doughy. (pro-tip: eat it while it is hot or else the dumplings can get sticky and break leaving you with no soup inside).
- Free egg custard buns with a Yelp check-in. Score!

Okay:
-Short rib lamian - each bowl was shareable among 2-3 people.
-The fried rice with asparagus - we all liked it but it was not awesome for the price.

The meh:
-Chicken thigh in claypot- didn't like anything in this dish for the price. the flavor was not appealing and it was douched in a brown sauce that felt very salty(msg?).  
-generally speaking the food seems rather salty and we needed more water.
-The high top seats by the wall were awkward, it felt like the table was too far from the seat and too far from your friends.
- Service was par to sub par. I don't find it useful when the waiter basically reads the entire menu to us page by page. I had to prompt him to get the highlights which involved more page turning.
- the staff was almost too eager to clear plates and they forgot to box some leftover fried rice.

Overall, it's not likely I would return in the near future...plus I love the places in Chinatown way more to pay these prices.

This restaurant lost 2 stars due to their rude waitress. The food was really good but service makes a big difference to the dining experience. I even gave the restaurant a chance to handle this situation before I took to my Yelping, but they just ignored me.
I'll get the bad part out of the way first. My boyfriend and I were here on a weekday for dinner, got seated at the bar area, waited a solid 5 minutes before our waitress, even came to our table. When we got seated the restaurant wasn't that busy. She comes to us but only looks and talks to my boyfriend, as if I'm invisible. I have never had any wait staff at all multitude of restaurants I've gone to talk only to my boyfriend. I was initially shocked but of course my boyfriend didn't notice. She only looked at me when I spoke up to put in a drink order. Later when she came back to see if we (or rather my boyfriend) had any questions about the menu, she was so shocked (even my boyfriend, a not very observant guy, noticed how stupidly shocked she was) that we had no questions. (Well, maybe because I'm Chinese?) so my boyfriend orders the food and I chime in to force the waitress to even acknowledge my existence. Later when the food comes out she pops in by the table, looks directly at my boyfriend, and asks how the food is. Then she comes by again later, asks only him if he's good on drinks. I'm really angry about this because it's really sad that a Chinese female gets treated like this at Chinese restaurant of all places. I've dealt with racism and sexism enough but seriously? At a Chinese effing restaurant and being purposely ignored by a Latina waitress. There's really no excuse for her behavior. It's basic etiquette to speak to the entire party that you are waiting on. In no way did I feel like she was hitting on my man, I just think that she was fine ignoring me because I was either Asian, female, or both.

Later on my boyfriend wanted soy sauce so I tried flagging down another waitress. She had this bitchy attitude that we had asked her to do something and she came back and kind of just threw it on the table and left.  

Well on to the food. The xiao long bao (soup dumplings) had lots of soup in them! It would have been nice if we got spoons when the soup dumplings were brought out though. We had to ask for spoons and the bus boy seemed to think it was an odd request. The dim sum platter was a nice variety of foods... Mostly seafood based. The fried platter was good but we could have done without it.

Overall good experience! The only reason I'm giving 4 instead of 5 stars is because the service was a tad slow tonight, maybe they were just busy. Make a reservation! You won't regret it. Otherwise you will be waiting upwards of 2 hours for a table for 2! Such good food!

I had an absolutely exquisite experience. We were looking for a nice dinner to end our girls night on and we were curious of the colorful xiao long bao pictures we've seen.

Presentation was a big part of this dining experience, I was wowed by each dish that was placed before us. However taste falls flat on some of them. Service was attentive, but I felt our waitress lacked knowledge on some of the food.

Combination xiao long bao - a great way to sample their offerings, the combination included traditional Shanghai, spicy Szechuan, gruyere, crab, truffle, and duck. I expected savory dumpling juice to spill out when I bite into them, only some did... definitely disappointed by that. Flavor-wise, after sampling all of them, i am only willing to order spicy Szechuan and gruyere again.

Salted egg yolk green bean - a special of the day. Lightly tempura battered green bean cooked with salted egg yolk. I love it!

Pumpkin puff and crispy wonton - Very cute presentation and taste followed through. Crispy wonton had a shrimp filling, delicious. The pumpkin puff was the most memorable bite I had that night. The black pepper pork filling was so good and all that goodness was stuffed inside a crispy on the outside, chewy on the inside rice flour dough. Very similar to a fried salty dumpling.

Braised pork belly la mian - their house made noodle, A++. The pork belly you could tell was braised for hours to get that depth of flavor. All served in a clean light broth.

Lunar blossom dessert - what a show! Very fun to end the meal on. The white chocolate shell "blossomed" open to reveal a light pandan cake with toasted almond and rich vanilla ice cream. Very sweet and rich dessert, but nevertheless delicious. A pricy dessert I would only save for special occasion.

Interesting take on Dimsum. Came by around 7 pm on Friday and did not have to wait. Plenty of empty tables still empty. The interior decoration and stuff was all very cute and would a great date spot. Food was a little pricey for what you get but everything was delicious.

Location: 5-star
Service: 5-star
Food: 3-star
Price: 2-star

A nice addition of upscale Chinese spots in River North. You really can't beat the location, right off Michigan and close to all the shopping and night life around River North. Indoor decor is like a 20th-century Chinese dining room, very traditional and beautiful. Service is very attentive. Added bonus that you can almost always get a reservation. A very well-run establishment.

Food wise, many dishes are very photogenic, but quite average tasting, and overpriced. My favorite is the pumpkin puffs; they are cutely shaped just like pumpkins on the ground (even with arugula vines, lol), and filled with pumpkin cream. The assorted (rainbow) Xiao Long Bao is a feast to the eye, but tastes meh. The lobster fried rice is also very ambitiously plated, but very overpriced for the amount of lobster (and just food in general) you get. And the entree noodles I don't quite care for either.

But will I come back? For the convenience, most likely yes.

review.des: Extremely disappointed with the service last night. They served us soup dumplings but didn't give us spoons to eat them with because they ran out of spoons! We couldn't eat them and when our waitress finally brought out the spoons the dumplings were cold and unenjoyable. Very sad night.

Yeah yeah, I was just there on 10/23.  Guess what, me and La J went back again.  Those damn shrimp dumplings were calling me.  These are not your typical shrimp dumplings...they have actual whole shrimp in them and they are soooo good!

We got there in time to do the Happy Hour, which again, is a really good deal.  For drinks I started with the Jackson Estate Flight (Chardonnay).  You get two 3 oz pours of the Santa Maria Valley (2014) and the Camelot Highlands (2014).  Both were nice.  I then switched over to the Happy Hour white selection, which also was not bad, especially at $5 a glass (Scarpetta, Frico Bianco, Italy).  Me and La J laughed at the thought of an Italian white wine with Asian food, but it worked.  There was also a selection of non-alcoholic drinks.  La J got a drink called Shaman (cranberry, grape, mallorca melon, lime and ginger beer).  It was very good and I mentioned that it would be great mixed with a little champagne.

In additional to the shrimp dumplings, we got the Gua Bao (Braised pork belly, spinach steamed bun).  There were three pieces in the order and they were of a nice size.  The pork that was in each bun was a nice size.  We also got the Duck Xiao Long Bao and the Pumpkin Puffs.  Both were great and what was nice was the amount of duck in each dish.  Not sure if the Pumpkin Puffs are just for this month...I am going to call to find out as they are good.

Honestly, you can do dumplings and bao at this place and never hit a ramen bowl, it is that fillings.  For dessert we got a free order of the Salted Egg Bao (Steamed Molten Egg Custard Bun).  It sounds like a combination of flavors that would not work, but it does.  Light and refreshing, i could totally do these with champagne as a brunch item.  You will get this free once  you check in on Yelp and it is work it.

La J and I have decided that this is going to become our regular monthly Happy Hour place for dumplings and bao

Pork belly bun...nice ratio of fat and meat, which melted in the mouth

review.des:
My family and I went here on a whim one evening while we were visiting Chicago because it was right across the street from our hotel. It turned out to be an excellent decision because I LOVED Imperial Lamian! Since we were going for light bites, we ordered several small plates to share: the combination xiao long bao (soup dumplings), calamari, rojak tofu and Lotus (or was it Lunar?) Blossom dessert. The xiao long bao is a must because it comes with an assortment of different flavors: shanghai, spicy Szechuan, crab, truffle, Gruyere and duck. Our favorites were the truffle, crab and duck. On a side note, this dish makes for great food pics since the dumplings are all different colors and you don't see that at a lot of places lol. The calamari was surprisingly really good too. I normally consider calamari a basic dish that tastes similar at most places, but the one at Imperial Lamian was tossed in a sweet sauce and had the perfect amount of crunch.

I have a huge sweet tooth, so when our server mentioned dessert, I jumped on the opportunity to stuff my face. She recommended the Lotus Blossom, which was pandan cake with almond slivers and strawberries baked inside a giant white chocolate shell. If you're unsure what pandan is, it's a sweet, light flavor similar to vanilla, but it's green. She drizzled hot chocolate on top until the chocolate shell melted to reveal the cake inside. It was a truly beautiful experience and probably my favorite dessert of all time. I ate every single bite! This is saying a lot considering the Lotus Blossom dessert was large enough to be split among at least four people. But hey, it was a steal at $15. Can I go back now?

A cold, windy day in Chicago had me wanting some hot soupy comfort food. Stumbled on Imperial Lamian because of Yelp and had a hit the spot meal.

The pork and shrimp dumplings (Siew Mai 7$/4pc) are tasty. The dumplings are topped with masago and comes with a ponzu like dipping sauce. If you want some spice, ask for chili oil a.k.a sate.

Char Siu & Wonton (16$) LaMian caught my eyes. Fresh hand pulled noodles in pork broth with bok choy, char siu, wonton, cilantro, and green onion. The pork broth was light but flavorful. The char siu (bbq pork) was okay, I had better. The wonton, also ok. I added the left over chili oil into my bowl for some needed heat.

Dining companion had the Mince Pork (14$) LaMian. This was way better than my choice. The truffle oil truly enhanced the pork broth. It was so flavorful.

We also tried the Oxtail Fried Rice (16$) and Green Beans (9$). The fried rice was good. The fattiness of the oxtail makes the dish. The green beans were meh. The ends weren't cut off, which made the green beans difficult to swallow. Also, it was over cooked and mushy-like.

review.des: The only thing great about this place is the ambience. I've never been to a restaurant where the server knows nothing about the food they serve and I've never had such poor service in the city. My waitress was a hot mess, it was Labor Day so I knew she was short handed but the wait for our food was not the issue, our service was so bad. Our waitress failed to tell us that the food comes out as it's prepared so we had two meals come out and my meal came when everyone had finished eating, I honestly think she forgot to put in the order. I asked what was in the truffle soup dumplings and she said "truffle" I also asked if there was any pork in them and she said no but since she knew nothing about the menu I asked her to ask the kitchen and they confirmed there was pork. It's pretty disappointing when your server can't even tell you the ingredients in popular dishes on the menu. Why would you lie about ingredients when people could have allergies or even religious views that prevent them from eating certain things. The food was overpriced for taste, I had a shrimp noodle stir fry, I think it was called wok fried lai man and it tasted no different than Chinese takeout. There were only 2 pieces of shrimp in my whole dish. I also ordered a bubble tea and the tapioca pearls were hard. My friends ordered la mian which were the noodles in broth, both of them said it was nothing special. For soup noodles or authentic Chinese food, don't go here! You're better off sticking to china town :)

pics.caption: Where is the shrimp? "Shrimp" Wok fried La Mian

review.des:
Been here twice, both for happy hour. Overall, the happy hour menu is a great deal, esp for the area. Each bao order comes with 3-4 so its easy to share and the portion size for the noodles is generous as well. I've tried the pork and mushroom hand shaved noodles and both were delicious. I love that you can watch the chefs make the noodles right in front of you as well!  

Only caveat, the pumpkin bubble tea and it was disgusting. It was not pumpkin flavored at all, was sour and the bubbles were mushy and gross. Definitely do not get it.
